Tell Me More

About

In this website, we will educate you, the reader, on the history of cryptography, provide examples of how cryptography has changed the nature of how we as a society communicate, and finally provide advice on how you can properly protect yourself using encryption.

Why is this information important? With the development of technology and our continued reliance on it, more and more information lives one the internet. While this is an incredible achievement of mankind, new security concerns continue to develop alongside said technology. In order to stay safe when interacting with the internet it is important to stay up to date with basic security knowledge. The average person is often chronically behind on what risks/threats they face, the implications of these risks, and how simple steps can be taken to prevent harm. Throughout this webpage we hope to provide a baseline of how Cryptographical security has developed, different techniques used within the domain, and wifi safety understandable by a non tech user. This should only be used as a starting point and to spark further interest in such an important topic.

History

    Cryptography's Humble Beginnings

    The Beginning- Sending hidden, secret, hard to read messages has always been a struggle throughout history. At first this was achieved by hiding the message, this was done by swallowing the message, or using invisible ink. Then came hiding the meaning, this is were cryptography began. One of the first cryptographic examples is from the Romans; the Ceaser shift.

WiFi Fundamentals

What is WiFi?

We are all very familiar with WiFi, but how does it work? Simply put, WiFi uses radio frequencies to communicate between devices. These radio frequencies are measured in gigahertz (GHz). There are two standard frequencies: 2.5GHz and 5GHz. 2.5GHz provides a wider range of coverage at slower speeds, and 5GHz provides faster speeds at shorter ranges. A WiFi modum connects to a wired internet connection which is interconnected with all other networks; this is the “internet”. A router takes incoming data and routes it to the correct device on the network, or takes outgoing data and routes it to the modum which communicates with the “internet”. Devices can connect to the router wirelessly or wired. The wireless portion is referred to as wireless fidelity or WiFi.

Vulnerabilites over WiFi

Joining public Wi-Fi is a dangerous activity, as someone could be eavesdropping at any time. Anyone who is on the same network as you can eavesdrop on what you send and receive through packet sniffing. Packet sniffing is not always a malicious activity, in fact GVSU network administrators likely perform it daily to monitor network traffic, analyze security issues and perform troubleshooting. Though, it can also be used for malicious purposes by black hat hackers to listen for and read unencrypted information that is sent to and from a device on a network. Below are some of the dangers of joining unsecured public networks.

An Evil Twin attack is a man-in-the-middle attack whereby a hacker impersonates a legitimate Wi-Fi network to trick someone into connecting. For example, say you are at a coffee shop and you see two networks listed: BobsBarista and BobsBaristaGuest. Bob only has one Wi-Fi network, BobsBarista, which has a password on it. Let's say you are working on your laptop and decide to join the free guest network. Well in reality this network isn't Bob’s, rather it is a fake hotspot someone created to eavesdrop on what you do while connected to the network.

If a network is not protected, an attacker could plant malware such as viruses, worms, trojan horses, ransomware, adware, etc. on your device.

How to protect yourself over WiFi

Try to join “free” or public Wi-Fi networks as little as possible. This is your best bet in keeping your information safe and secure. If you do need to join a public network make sure you use a Virtual Private Network (VPN). A VPN adds a layer of protection to your device; it is like a private digital tunnel that delivers your information to its intended destination privately and securely. A VPN hides your IP address and encrypts all of the digital traffic on your device. This allows you to browse the web safely without worrying about hackers watching what you're doing and stealing your information. A good VPN will have end-to-end encryption, this means information is safe and encrypted while on your device and even after you send it to someone else. So, even if hackers do intercept your encrypted traffic, they will not be able to view it.

To keep unwanted visitors on your home Wi-Fi network, ensure that you have an up to date form of encryption on your router. Some older routers are outdated and have old forms of encryption. The most popular form of encryption right now is WPA 3. Having a strong Wi-Fi password is also very important, you may be tempted to create a simple password so you can memorize it, and make it easier for your friends and family to join. Attempt to digress from this, as having a weak password can be dangerous to you and the people on your network.

Caesar Shift Cipher

Used extensively during the height of the Roman Empire, its most famous version is named after the Roman emperor Julius Caesar

Below is a WEAK cipher that encrypts a message by organizing the message (without spaces) into columns with the original message reading left to right. A keyword is used to jumble the text up. A keyword must first be chosen to define the number of columns that will be needed. The key word is the top row of the table and when ready to encrypt all one must do is rearrange the columns and copy from left to right and top to bottom the new encrypted text to send the message and then provide the key word to the receiver of the message. The new ciphertext is just a permutation of the cleartext.

Encrypted Text: RENEVAOJNIEUNSNDUCERNIWIFTEOWK

Key Word: Crypt

Decryption Process: Once you know the key word you can start by writing from left to right the encrypted message into columns below the jumbled key word.

Once you complete the first step, you can then position the columns to be in the correct position. From here you just need to write out each letter again from left to right, top to bottom, and figure out where the spaces should go.

This form of encryption is weak. One reason is because if an unintended recipient of the message finds out the length of the keyword then they will know which columns go first if the length of the plaintext is not a multiple of the length of the key word. This can be seen above as column C has 7 characters while the rest have 6. Other reasons they are considered weak is because they do not change the letters in the plaintext nor do they mask any frequencies.

  • Possible Combinations: 25
  • Advantages: Easy to use and implement on the battlefield
  • Disadvantages: Easily broken using frequency analysis, or if you can deduce the key used to shift the cipher

Vigenere Cipher

invented in 1553 by the Italian cryptographer Giovan Battista Bellaso but for centuries was attributed to the 16th-century French cryptographer Blaise de Vigenère, who devised a similar cipher in 1586.

Use this area to describe your project. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Est blanditiis dolorem culpa incidunt minus dignissimos deserunt repellat aperiam quasi sunt officia expedita beatae cupiditate, maiores repudiandae, nostrum, reiciendis facere nemo!

  • Possible Combinations: 5,429,503,678,976
    • Advantages: Not susceptible to frequency analysis due to the fact that the cipher rotates through different shifts, so the same plaintext letter will not always be encrypted to the same ciphertext letter.
  • Disadvantages: If the key length is smaller than the plaintext length, then the key will be repeated

Hill Cipher

Invented by Lester S. Hill in 1929, it was the first polygraphic cipher in which it was practical (though barely) to operate on more than three symbols at once.

The Hill cypher, an example of a polygraphic substitution cypher, performs a uniform substitution cypher across all levels of blocks. To encrypt a message, the clear text is first converted into numbers corresponding to their order in the designated alphabet. A key is chosen based on the designated block size. The numbers representing the message are then placed into a plaintext vectors of size n, and multiplied by the key matrix of size n * n. This is followed by obtaining the modulo of each plaintext vector, and the process is completed for each block. The decryption process is almost identical but with one key difference. Each vector, now a ciphertext vector, is multiplied by the inverse matrix to the key. This is repeated for each ciphertext vector. Now all that is left is to convert the numbers back into letters/symbols using the numerical values and the Hill cipher has been used to both encrypt and decrypt a message.

While this encryption algorithm is more complex than some of its predecessors such as the caesar cipher, it is still considered a weak encryption algorithm by today's standards. Systems with linear ciphertext pairs can break the encryption, and adding complexity to the matrix multiplication algorithm does not significantly improve security.

  • Possible Combinations: 12,303,585,972,327,392,870,400 (12 septillion)
  • Advantages: disguising letter frequencies of the plaintext, its simplicity because of using matrix multiplication and inversion for encryption and decryption, and its high speed and high throughput.
  • Disadvantages: it can be cracked by taking n distinct pairs of plaintext and corresponding cipher-text

RSA Encryption

Invented in 1977 by Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir and Len Adleman

RSA encryption is significantly more complex than the weak encryption techniques previously mentioned. With said complexity comes a much more secure technique. RSA is still used to this day, almost fifty years after its birth. While RSA may be slow and not used to protect large data sets, it is frequently implemented to encrypt public keys used in other algorithms. One common use of RSA today is to pass around symmetric keys used by SSL and internet browsers. RSA uses an asymmetric key technique, which allows for the combined use of public and private keys. This was a breakthrough moment for cryptography as keys previously needed to be shared between parties. The technique to use RSA is long and tedious, but relies on modulus and prime numbers such as other encryption algorithms. Large primes allow it to be almost unbreakable, and this technique will likely be around for years to come.

  • Estimated time to break: 300 trillion years (RSA-2048 bit encryption key)
  • Advantages: RSA is considered to be the strongest encryption technique using symmetrical keys, and has issues involving authenticity and confidentiality.
  • Disadvantages: A lot of computation power is necessary to run this process and it takes large amounts of time to perform it on big sets of informational messages.

Quantum Encryption

theorized as early as 1984, it is now on the cusp of viability with modern day technology

The idea of quantum cryptography is one of the newest in the field. With the advancement in computing technology, an idea for unbreakable encryption has become sought after. Most modern encryption today is considered to be unbreakable within a reasonable amount of time. With cutting edge technologies, such as quantum computing, these algorithms would become obsolete.

So what is quantum encryption? Instead of relying on math, the laws of physics play a major role in this process. More specifically, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle is what is behind this technique. Photons are sent to the recipient as keys. These photons can have vertical, diagonal, or horizontal spin, and are passed through filters that are either rectilineal or diagonal to read either ones or zeros. This prevents unintended recipients from learning the key.

Now you may ask, how does the intended recipient get the key? The sender must share which type of filter was used for each photon with the recipient. This allows them to tell which filters were correct, and allows for the use of around half the original key digits to be used. This prevents snooping, and also allows for it to be known whether or not the message had an attempt to intercept.

    Estimated time to break: Unknown
  • Advantages: due to the nature of encrypting using quantum mechanics, you the reciever would always know if it was intercepted. it is almost virtually unbreakable using classical decryption methods
  • Disadvantages: Theoretically, quantum decryption methods not yet invented could breach the machanics surrounding the encryption process

Unbreakable Encryption

Originally described in 1882 by banker Frank Miller (USA), it was re-invented in 1917 by Gilbert Vernam and Joseph Mauborgne.

The one-time pad (OTP) is an encryption technique that cannot be cracked, but requires the use of a single-use pre-shared key that is not smaller than the message being sent. In order to perform this encryption technique, you must generate n amount of keys for n amount of letters in the message to be encrypted. This is usually done randomly within any given alphabet and one key is paired with each letter. The message letters are then stored with their corresponding key, both in bitwise notation. This results with each letter of the plaintext message being completely randomized in accordance with its key. To decrypt the message one symply xor’s the bitwise version of each key with its corresponding ciphertext letter.

    Possible Combinations: Infinite
  • Advantages: By never using the same key twice for each message, you achieve unbreakable encryption
  • Disadvantages: exhaustive to create a random key pad every single time manually. physical key books exist for ever recipient. High chance of human error in using the key pad
